intro: Acalypha virginica var. ramosa, commonly known as the hairy ironweed, is a herbaceous perennial native to the southeastern United States. It features upright, branching stems covered in fine, soft hairs, which give it its common name. The plant produces clusters of small, greenish-white flowers surrounded by red bracts, creating an attractive visual display. Its leaves are ovate to lance-shaped with serrated edges and a hairy surface. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wetlands and along stream banks.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acalypha virginica var. ramosa is primarily native to the southeastern United States, including states such as Florida, Georgia, South Carolina, and North Carolina. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is commonly found in woodland edges, swamps, and along stream banks. This variant is particularly adapted to humid climates and is often seen in wetland habitats. It is also occasionally found in parts of Texas and the Caribbean islands. The plant plays an important role in local ecosystems by providing habitat and food for various wildlife species.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acalypha virginica var. ramosa was mainly introduced to the eastern and central United States. It is commonly found in disturbed habitats such as roadsides, fields, and along stream banks. This plant is known for its rapid growth and ability to thrive in a variety of soil conditions. It has been reported in several states including Maryland, Virginia, and North Carolina. Its introduction has raised concerns due to its potential to become invasive in certain ecosystems.
